subject: Sleep
title: Hibernation Is Not Just Sleep
description: One-minute skill: Hibernation Is Not Just Sleep.

hook.text: Bears hibernate for months but wake up groggy and sleep-deprived. That's because hibernation isn't actually sleep.

buildup.text: Hibernation is a state of torpor where body temperature, heart rate, and metabolism plummet far below sleep levels.

discovery.text: Hibernating animals periodically warm up and enter true sleep, suggesting the brain needs sleep even during torpor.

twist.text: These warming-and-sleeping episodes cost 90 percent of the energy used during hibernation. Sleep is that essential.

climax.text: Torpor suppresses brain function so deeply that real sleep is needed to restore it, even in an unconscious animal.

punchline.text: Hibernation is so deep the brain wakes up just to sleep.

quiz.question: Why do hibernating animals periodically warm up during hibernation?
options: They need to enter true sleep, which can't occur during deep torpor
